archimate:BusinessObject.name: EU policy on Cyber Defense
archimate:BusinessObject.documentation:
Short about purpose and target group The policy is mentioned for the first time in the Strategic Compass which was presented in 2022 to further develop the EU's cybersecurity framework. The strategic compass points out a common direction for member states where defense should include the cyber domain and that cyber defense should act as a sort of umbrella for all cyber issues. On 10 November 2022, a joint communication on a cyber defense policy was presented, produced by the European External Action Service (EEAS) together with the Commission and the European Defense Agency (EDA). The Communication aims to strengthen the Union's cyber defense capabilities, including the Member States' ability to conduct joint cyber operations, strengthen coordination, information sharing and cooperation between cyber security and cyber defence. 7 The policy aims at more effective cyber crisis management within the EU and to help reduce strategic dependencies on critical cyber technology and at the same time strengthen the European defense technological industrial base (The EU's Defense Technological and Industrial Base, EDTIB) in the area.
It is important to highlight the policy as a kind of framework or document of will for how a member state should implement and launch the initiatives the policy prescribes to achieve cyber solidarity.
The policy will also promote training and exercise, the ability to attract and retain competence in the cyber area and expand cooperation with the EU's partners in cyber defence.
The most important commitments for Sweden The policy should be understood as a direction for how the Commission and the EEAS view the EU's current and future investments and developments in cyber defence. The goal is to streamline common situational images, preparations, response and recovery in the event of cyber attacks, based on the implementation proposals and plans mentioned in the policy.
The policy proposes that a "cyber task force" should be established within the EU which should be able to assist organizations with penetration tests, vulnerability scans, advice and incident management.
It also proposes the establishment of a cyber reserve consisting of EU-based services trusted private providers who, with the support of funds from the EU, can be sent to organizations or authorities in the event of significant cross-border incidents.
7 EU Policy on Cyber Defence, Joint Communication to the European Parliament and the council, Brussels, 10.11.2022 JOIN(2022) 49 final, page 1 Introduction. https://www.eeas.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Comm_cyber%20defence.pdf
The policy proposes far-reaching proposals for expanded work with cyber defense within the EU. Among other things, it is proposed that a coordination center for military cyber defense issues be established, Security Operations Center (SOC) activities be built up, integration with NATO be established, the cyber diplomatic toolbox be strengthened, regulation of the defense sector be introduced, new efforts to regulate and finance "critical cyber technologies" be introduced, etc.
The most important opportunities for Sweden, including the impact on security Several of the proposals in the joint communication on a cyber defense policy could lead to major changes to both cyber defense and cyber security cooperation in the EU. Cyber defense is based on capabilities that are entirely within the mandate of the member states, while the European Commission has the right to propose laws in the area of cyber security.
If the policy's proposals are implemented, it could have far-reaching effects in a number of areas that affect cyber security, secure communications, space issues and protection of critical infrastructure. MSB believes that the policy's proposals must be weighed against the member states' right to govern themselves how national security is to be organized and ensured.
The government welcomes the common skills development policy advocates and emphasizes that cyber security must be based on the individual needs of the member states. The government also emphasizes that the EU's strategic partnership with NATO continues to be of central importance, and cooperation should thus be characterized by complementarity. 8
Time perspective (when it starts to apply) As this is a joint communication and not legally binding, there are no specified timeframes but the Commission and the High Representative will present an annual report to monitor and assess progress in implementation. Member States are encouraged to provide feedback on how implementation measures are progressing nationally or collaboratively. An implementation plan could be drawn up in cooperation with the Member States.
The cyber defense policy is dealt with during the Swedish EU presidency, which extends between 1 January and 30 June 2023.
